title: 107_s3036
content: The Act is titled the "Corps of Engineers River Stewardship Independent Investigation and Review Act" and defines terms such as Commission, Indian tribe, and session day. It establishes the Commission for independent investigation and review. The Act establishes the "Corps of Engineers River Stewardship Independent Investigation and Review Commission" with 22 members representing various interests such as the Department of the Army, Department of the Interior, Department of Justice, environmental, hydropower, flood control, recreational, and navigation interests. The "Corps of Engineers River Stewardship Independent Investigation and Review Commission" includes members representing various interests such as navigation, environmental, governors from different regions, and representatives of Indian tribes. Members are appointed for the life of the Commission, with appointments to be made within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Commission members are appointed for life, vacancies do not affect the Commission's powers and are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The initial meeting must be held within 30 days of all members being appointed. Meetings are called by the Chairperson, and a majority of members constitute a quorum. The President selects the Chairperson and Vice Chairperson from Commission members. The Chairperson and Vice Chairperson of the Commission are selected by the President from among its members, excluding representatives from the Department of the Army. SEC. 4. INVESTIGATION OF CORPS OF ENGINEERS. The Commission will investigate and report to Congress on the management of rivers in the US by the Corps of Engineers, focusing on compliance with environmental and cultural resource laws. The Commission will investigate river management projects, including compliance with environmental and cultural resource laws such as the National Historic Preservation Act, Archaeological Resources Protection Act, Native American Graves Protection Act, and Executive Order 13007. Opportunities for tribal cooperative management agreements and policy review on sensitive information disclosure will also be examined. The Commission will investigate the quality of scientific, environmental, and economic analyses by the Corps of Engineers, as well as their coordination with Federal and State agencies and Indian tribes. The Commission will investigate river management projects, studies by the Corps of Engineers, independent review, amending river planning laws, and transferring river management functions to a Federal civilian agency. The Commission has the power to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, use postal services, and accept gifts or donations. SEC. 6. COMMISSION PERSONNEL MATTERS. Members of the Commission are compensated based on their status as federal employees or non-federal employees. Non-federal employees receive daily pay equivalent to level IV of the Executive Schedule, while federal employees serve without additional compensation. Travel expenses, including per diem, are provided for Commission members. The Chairperson of the Commission may appoint an executive director and additional staff without following civil service laws. The executive director's employment is subject to confirmation by the Commission, and their compensation is determined by the Chairperson. The Chairperson of the Commission has the authority to set the compensation for the executive director and staff without following certain federal pay regulations. The maximum pay rate for these positions is capped at the level V of the Executive Schedule. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without losing their civil service status. The Chairperson of the Commission can procure temporary and intermittent services at rates not exceeding the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay for level V of the Executive Schedule under title 5, United States Code. Authorization of appropriations for $5,000,000 annually from 2003 to 2005 to carry out the Act. The Commission will terminate upon submitting the report to Congress.
